signs: Fever (often high)
Chills and rigors
Headache
Vomiting, sweating, fatigue
Danger signs: altered consciousness, high respiratory rate, inability to drink, seizures
causes: Protozoan parasites of the genus Plasmodium transmitted by infected Anopheles mosquitoes
prevention: Use insecticide-treated bed nets (ITNs)
Indoor residual spraying where available
Drain or cover stagnant water near homes
Prompt testing and treatment of cases to reduce transmission
treatment: Prompt diagnosis (rapid diagnostic test / microscopy) and effective antimalarial therapy (as per national guidelines)
Supportive care for fever and dehydration
Refer severe cases to a facility for parenteral therapy and monitoring
advice: If fever occurs, test for malaria immediately and seek treatment if positive
Seek urgent care for danger signs (difficulty breathing, seizures, unconsciousness)
malawi_context: Seek care at the nearest health centre or district hospital; Health Surveillance Assistants (HSAs) provide community-level support and referral.
Follow Malawi Ministry of Health guidance for first-line antimalarials and case management.

signs: Early: fever, weight loss, persistent swollen lymph nodes
Advanced: chronic infections, opportunistic infections, wasting
Danger signs: severe weight loss, persistent high fever, severe breathing difficulty
causes: Infection with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) transmitted via unprotected sex, contaminated blood, shared needles, or mother-to-child transmission
prevention: Consistent use of condoms
Safe blood and injection practices
Testing and treatment of pregnant women to prevent mother-to-child transmission
Needle-safety programs and harm reduction
treatment: Antiretroviral therapy (ART) as per national guidelines to suppress viral load
Prophylaxis and treatment for opportunistic infections
Adherence support and linkage to care
advice: Continue ART unless advised by a clinician; do not stop therapy without consulting healthcare provider
Test if exposed or symptomatic; pregnant women should access antenatal services with HIV testing and treatment
malawi_context: HSAs and ART clinics at health centres/district hospitals provide testing, linkage to ART, and follow-up.
Malawi has national ART programs—follow local protocols for registration and drug pick-up.
sources: Local Ministry of Health ART guidance

signs: Persistent cough for 2+ weeks
Weight loss, night sweats, fever
Danger signs: severe respiratory distress, haemoptysis, severe weakness
causes: Bacterial infection (Mycobacterium tuberculosis) spread by airborne droplets from a person with pulmonary TB
prevention: Early diagnosis and treatment of active cases (reduces transmission)
Good ventilation in homes and public spaces
BCG vaccination for infants as per schedule
treatment: Standard multi-drug TB therapy under direct observation / national TB program (first-line and second-line for resistant TB)
Complete full course; monitor for side effects and adherence
advice: If cough persists more than 2 weeks, seek testing at a health centre
Inform contacts and seek testing for household members
malawi_context: TB diagnosis and treatment are available through health centres and district hospitals; follow the Malawi National TB Program for regimens and follow-up.

signs: Acute watery diarrhea (often profuse)
Vomiting
Rapid dehydration and thirst
Danger signs: sunken eyes, dry mouth, low urine output, lethargy
causes: Bacterial infection (Vibrio cholerae) from contaminated water or food
prevention: Drink and use safe water (boil or treat), practice hand hygiene
Ensure safe food handling and sanitation
Vaccination in outbreak-prone areas where recommended
treatment: Rapid rehydration with oral rehydration solution (ORS) for most cases
Intravenous fluids for severe dehydration; antibiotics for severe cases as per guidelines
Monitor electrolytes and refer if severe
advice: Seek urgent care for signs of dehydration
Improve household water, sanitation, and hygiene practices
malawi_context: During outbreaks, local health authorities provide cholera treatment centres and mass communication on safe water and sanitation.

signs: Excessive thirst, frequent urination, fatigue, unexplained weight loss
Long-term: poor wound healing, vision changes, neuropathy
causes: Type 1: autoimmune destruction of insulin-producing cells; Type 2: insulin resistance and relative insulin deficiency; lifestyle and genetic factors
prevention: Healthy diet and regular physical activity (especially for Type 2)
Maintain healthy weight, avoid tobacco use
treatment: Blood sugar monitoring, lifestyle measures, oral hypoglycemic agents or insulin as per clinician
Regular follow-up for complications (eyes, kidneys, feet)
advice: If symptoms suggest high blood sugar, check at a clinic; maintain medication adherence
Attend routine screening for complications
malawi_context: Chronic disease clinics in health centres/district hospitals provide follow-up and medicines; screening programs may be available through primary care.

signs: Often asymptomatic
Possible headaches, dizziness; danger signs include chest pain, shortness of breath, sudden weakness (stroke signs)
causes: Multifactorial: diet high in salt, obesity, sedentary lifestyle, age, genetics, kidney disease
prevention: Reduce salt intake, maintain healthy weight, exercise, avoid tobacco and excess alcohol
treatment: Lifestyle modification and antihypertensive medicines as prescribed; regular blood pressure monitoring
advice: Regular check-ups since hypertension is often silent; seek care for extremely high readings or stroke symptoms
malawi_context: Primary care clinics offer BP screening and medication; community screening events may be organized by health programmes.

signs: Cough, difficulty breathing, chest pain, fever
In children: fast breathing and lower chest wall indrawing are key danger signs
causes: Viruses or bacteria (e.g., Streptococcus pneumoniae), sometimes fungi
prevention: Vaccination (where available), hand hygiene, breastfeeding for infants, reduce indoor air pollution
treatment: Antibiotics for suspected bacterial pneumonia per guidelines, supportive oxygen therapy for severe cases, hydration and fever control
Refer severe cases for oxygen and inpatient care
advice: Seek immediate care for fast breathing, inability to feed, chest indrawing, or extreme lethargy
malawi_context: Integrated management of childhood illness (IMCI) guidelines used at primary care; HSAs and clinics assess fast breathing and refer as needed.

signs: Fever, abdominal pain, headache, weakness
Danger signs: severe abdominal pain, persistent high fever, suspected intestinal perforation
causes: Bacterial infection (Salmonella enterica serotype Typhi) via contaminated food/water
prevention: Safe water and food hygiene, handwashing, vaccination in high-risk settings
treatment: Appropriate antibiotics guided by local resistance patterns; supportive care for dehydration and complications
advice: Seek clinic care for persistent fever or severe abdominal pain
malawi_context: Follow local antibiotic guidelines and public-health measures to control outbreaks.

signs: Fever, cough, sore throat, shortness of breath, loss of taste/smell
Danger signs: severe difficulty breathing, persistent chest pain, confusion
causes: SARS-CoV-2 virus transmitted via respiratory droplets and aerosols
prevention: Vaccination, mask-wearing in high-risk settings, hand hygiene, isolation if symptomatic
treatment: Supportive care; oxygen therapy for severe disease; follow national treatment protocols for antivirals in indicated cases
advice: Test and isolate if symptomatic or exposed as per local guidance; seek urgent care for breathing difficulties
malawi_context: Malawi adopted national COVID-19 guidelines for testing, case management and vaccination campaigns (follow current MoH guidance).

signs: Recurrent wheeze, cough, chest tightness, shortness of breath
Danger signs: severe breathlessness at rest, inability to speak, cyanosis
causes: Chronic airway inflammation triggered by allergens, infections, exercise, smoke, cold air
prevention: Identify and avoid triggers (smoke, allergens), ensure adherence to preventive inhaled therapy where indicated
treatment: Short-acting bronchodilators for relief; inhaled corticosteroids for control; emergency treatment with oxygen and systemic steroids for severe attacks
advice: Have an action plan and seek urgent care for severe attacks or poor response to reliever inhalers
malawi_context: Access to inhalers and spacers may be limited—work with primary care clinics for supply and education; avoid indoor smoke exposure.

signs: Frequent loose or watery stools, abdominal cramps, dehydration
Danger signs: inability to drink, sunken eyes, lethargy, blood in stool
causes: Often infections (rotavirus, bacteria, parasites) or poor hygiene and unsafe water
prevention: Safe water and sanitation, handwashing, breastfeeding, vaccination (e.g., rotavirus), safe food handling
treatment: Oral rehydration solution (ORS) to prevent/treat dehydration, zinc supplementation for children, antibiotics only when indicated
advice: Seek urgent care for dehydration signs; continue feeding and breastfeeding during diarrhea
malawi_context: HSAs and clinics provide ORS/zinc; growth monitoring and nutrition counselling available at health centres.

signs: Jaundice (yellowing of skin/eyes), dark urine, fatigue, abdominal pain
Chronic infection may be asymptomatic for years
causes: Infection with hepatitis B virus transmitted via blood, sexual contact, or mother-to-child
prevention: Vaccination (birth dose and follow-up doses), safe injection and blood practices, screening of pregnant women
treatment: Antiviral therapy for chronic hepatitis B per guidelines; monitoring of liver function
advice: Seek testing if exposed or symptomatic; pregnant women should be screened for hepatitis B
malawi_context: Hepatitis B vaccination included in many national immunization schedules; follow MoH guidance for testing and treatment referral.

signs: Yellowing of skin and eyes, dark urine, pale stools, abdominal pain
Danger signs: signs of liver failure (confusion, bleeding), high fever with jaundice
causes: Many causes including viral hepatitis (A, B, C), hemolysis, neonatal jaundice, and liver disease
prevention: Vaccination for hepatitis A/B where available, safe food and water, good newborn care to prevent severe neonatal jaundice
treatment: Depends on cause: supportive care for liver disease, phototherapy for neonatal jaundice, antivirals for some hepatitis infections
advice: Seek prompt assessment for new-onset jaundice, especially in newborns or if accompanied by fever or confusion
malawi_context: Newborns with jaundice should be assessed quickly at a health facility for phototherapy or referral.
sources: WHO hepatitis and neonatal care resources

signs: Joint pain, stiffness (especially morning stiffness), reduced range of motion, swelling
Danger signs: sudden severe joint swelling, fever with joint pain (possible infection)
causes: Various causes: osteoarthritis (wear-and-tear), rheumatoid arthritis (autoimmune), infections
prevention: Maintain healthy weight, regular exercise, injury prevention
treatment: Pain control (paracetamol, NSAIDs where appropriate), physiotherapy, disease-modifying agents for inflammatory arthritis under specialist care
advice: Seek assessment for severe or rapidly worsening joint pain, or signs of infection
malawi_context: Primary care can provide pain management and referral to higher-level services for specialized care.

signs: Fever, severe headache, stiff neck, sensitivity to light, altered consciousness
In children: poor feeding, irritability, bulging fontanelle (infants)
causes: Viral, bacterial, or fungal infections causing inflammation of membranes around brain and spinal cord
prevention: Vaccination for common bacterial causes (e.g., Hib, pneumococcus, meningococcus) where available
Prompt treatment of infections
treatment: Urgent medical care; bacterial meningitis requires prompt intravenous antibiotics and supportive care
advice: Seek emergency care immediately for fever with neck stiffness or altered behaviour
malawi_context: Suspected meningitis is a medical emergency—go to the nearest district hospital or referral facility for rapid treatment.

signs: Painful or frequent urination, urgency, cloudy or strong-smelling urine, lower abdominal pain
Danger signs: fever, flank pain, vomiting (possible upper UTI/pyelonephritis)
causes: Bacterial infection, often E. coli, spreading into urinary tract
prevention: Good perineal hygiene, adequate hydration, prompt treatment of bladder infections
treatment: Appropriate antibiotics as per local guidelines; drink fluids and seek care if symptoms worsen
advice: Seek clinic care for fever or inability to pass urine; pregnant women with UTI need prompt treatment
malawi_context: Primary clinics can diagnose and treat UTIs; laboratory tests may be available at higher-level facilities.

signs: Fever, cough, coryza (runny nose), conjunctivitis, followed by rash
Danger signs: dehydration, pneumonia, encephalitis
causes: Measles virus transmitted via respiratory droplets
prevention: Measles vaccination according to national immunization schedule
High vaccine coverage to prevent outbreaks
treatment: Supportive care: hydration, vitamin A supplementation for children, treating complications
advice: Seek care for high fever, difficulty breathing, or signs of dehydration
malawi_context: Follow Malawi immunization schedule; during outbreaks, health authorities run vaccination campaigns and case management protocols.

signs: Skin: itching, rash, discoloration; Nails: thickening or discoloration; Systemic: depends on organ involved
causes: Overgrowth of fungi on skin or inside body; dermatophytes, yeasts (Candida), or systemic fungi
prevention: Keep skin clean and dry, avoid sharing personal items, good hygiene
treatment: Topical or oral antifungal medications depending on severity and location
advice: Seek care for persistent or spreading skin infections or signs of systemic illness
malawi_context: Primary care treats common fungal skin infections; severe or systemic infections require referral.

signs: Recurrent severe headache often with nausea, vomiting, sensitivity to light or sound
causes: Complex neurological disorder with genetic and environmental triggers
prevention: Identify and avoid triggers, regular sleep, stress management, lifestyle measures
treatment: Acute analgesics (paracetamol, NSAIDs) and antiemetics; preventive drugs for frequent attacks under clinician supervision
advice: Seek care for new severe headaches, changes in pattern, or focal neurological signs
malawi_context: Primary care provides initial management and referral for specialist evaluation when needed.

signs: Redness, swelling, warmth, pus, pain for bacterial infections; rash, itching for others
causes: Bacterial, viral, or fungal organisms entering the skin through cuts or breaks, poor hygiene, insect bites
prevention: Clean wounds, good hygiene, avoid sharing personal items
treatment: Clean and dress wounds; topical or oral antibiotics/antifungals as indicated; seek care for spreading infection
advice: Seek care for rapidly spreading redness, fever, severe pain, or pus
malawi_context: Community health workers can treat minor infections; refer severe cases to clinics.

signs: Sneezing, blocked or runny nose, sore throat, mild cough, low-grade fever
causes: Mostly caused by rhinoviruses and other respiratory viruses
prevention: Handwashing, cough etiquette, avoid close contact with sick people
treatment: Supportive care: rest, fluids, symptomatic relief (paracetamol for fever/pain)
advice: Seek care if high fever develops, breathing difficulty, or symptoms persist beyond 7 days
malawi_context: Self-care at home for mild illness; seek clinic care for high-risk people (infants, elderly, people with chronic disease).

signs: Fever, body aches, headache, cough, sore throat, chills
causes: Influenza viruses spread by respiratory droplets
prevention: Hand hygiene, respiratory etiquette, vaccination where available
treatment: Supportive care; antivirals for high-risk or severe cases per national guidance
advice: Seek care for difficulty breathing, chest pain, or severe weakness
malawi_context: Seasonal influenza surveillance and vaccination policies vary—follow Malawi MoH recommendations.

signs: Underweight, wasting (low weight-for-height), stunting (low height-for-age), swollen feet (edema), poor appetite
causes: Inadequate dietary intake, repeated infections, poor maternal nutrition, food insecurity
prevention: Exclusive breastfeeding for 6 months, appropriate complementary feeding, micronutrient supplementation, food security and dietary diversity
treatment: Community-based management of acute malnutrition (therapeutic feeding for severe wasting), nutritional rehabilitation, treat infections and provide micronutrients
advice: Attend growth monitoring and seek prompt care for weight loss or poor feeding
malawi_context: UNICEF/WHO-backed nutrition programs operate with MoH—HSAs support growth monitoring and referrals for therapeutic feeding centres where needed.

disease: Hepatitis (general reference included under Hepatitis B)
signs: Jaundice, fatigue, abdominal pain, dark urine
causes: Viral hepatitis (A, B, C), toxins, alcohol
prevention: Vaccination for hepatitis A/B, safe water/sanitation, safe blood practices
treatment: Supportive care and antiviral therapy when indicated
advice: Test and seek clinician care for persistent jaundice or risk exposures
malawi_context: Follow national immunization and screening schedules; refer chronic cases to specialist clinics.

signs: Fever, abdominal pain, headache, weakness
causes: Salmonella Typhi infection via contaminated food/water
prevention: Safe water, food hygiene, vaccination where recommended
treatment: Antibiotic therapy guided by local resistance patterns; rehydration and monitoring
advice: Seek clinic care for persistent fever or severe abdominal pain
malawi_context: Follow MoH outbreak response protocols and antibiotic recommendations.

signs: Painful urination, frequent urination, cloudy/strong urine
causes: Bacterial infection, often E. coli
prevention: Hydration, perineal hygiene, prompt treatment
treatment: Antibiotics as indicated
advice: Pregnant women with UTI need urgent treatment; seek clinic care if fever or flank pain present
malawi_context: Primary care evaluation and treatment available; laboratory testing at higher-level facilities.

signs: Fever, cough, conjunctivitis, rash
causes: Measles virus
prevention: Measles vaccine per immunization schedule
treatment: Supportive care including vitamin A for children
advice: Seek care for high fever or breathing difficulty
malawi_context: Vaccination campaigns and routine immunization delivered through health centres.

signs: Cough, fast breathing, chest indrawing, fever
causes: Bacteria or viruses (e.g., pneumococcus, influenza)
prevention: Vaccination, breastfeeding, hand hygiene
treatment: Antibiotics for bacterial pneumonia, oxygen for severe cases
advice: Urgent assessment for chest indrawing, inability to feed, or severe breathing difficulty
malawi_context: IMCI and facility-based protocols guide assessment and referral.

signs: Itching, rash, discoloration
causes: Dermatophytes, yeasts, environmental fungi
prevention: Good hygiene, keep skin dry
treatment: Topical/oral antifungals as needed
advice: Visit clinic for persistent infections
malawi_context: Primary care management with referral for systemic disease.

signs: Severe recurrent headache, nausea, light sensitivity
causes: Neurological disorder with triggers
prevention: Trigger management, stress reduction
treatment: Symptomatic medications; preventive therapy if frequent
advice: Seek care for new severe headaches or change in pattern
malawi_context: Primary care for initial management and referral when necessary.

signs: Redness, swelling, pus, itching
causes: Bacterial, fungal, viral infections
prevention: Clean wounds, hygiene
treatment: Topical/oral antimicrobials as indicated
advice: Seek care for spreading infections or systemic signs
malawi_context: Community-level management for minor infections; refer severe cases.

signs: Sneezing, blocked/runny nose, sore throat
causes: Rhinoviruses and other respiratory viruses
prevention: Hand hygiene, cough etiquette
treatment: Supportive care: rest and fluids
advice: Seek care if breathing difficulty or prolonged fever
malawi_context: Self-care for mild cases; clinic care for high-risk individuals.

signs: Fever, body aches, cough
causes: Influenza viruses
prevention: Vaccination, hygiene
treatment: Supportive care; antivirals as per guidelines
advice: Seek care if severe or high-risk
malawi_context: Follow MoH seasonal influenza guidance.

signs: Wasting, stunting, edema, poor feeding
causes: Insufficient nutrient intake, frequent infections
prevention: Breastfeeding, diverse diets, micronutrient programs
treatment: Therapeutic feeding for severe cases; treat infections
advice: Attend growth monitoring and seek referral for severe wasting
malawi_context: Nutrition programs run by MoH, UNICEF support, HSAs for screening and referral.

signs: Jaundice, fatigue, abdominal pain
causes: Hepatitis B virus
prevention: Vaccination and safe blood/injection practices
treatment: Antivirals for chronic infection
advice: Screen pregnant women and treat per national guidelines
malawi_context: Follow national immunization schedule and screening programs.

signs: Fever, abdominal pain, headache
causes: Salmonella Typhi from contaminated food/water
prevention: Safe water and food handling
treatment: Antibiotics as per local guidance
advice: Seek care for persistent fever
malawi_context: Follow MoH guidance for typhoid outbreaks and treatment.

signs: Painful urination, frequent urination
causes: Bacterial infection (commonly E. coli)
prevention: Hydration and hygiene
treatment: Antibiotics as indicated
advice: Pregnant women should seek prompt treatment
malawi_context: Primary care diagnosis and treatment available.

signs: Sudden high fever, often cyclical (chills, then fever, then sweating)
Severe headache
Nausea and vomiting
Muscle aches and fatigue
Rapid breathing and pulse
In severe cases: confusion, seizures, coma (cerebral malaria)
Jaundice (yellowing of skin and eyes) due to loss of red blood cells
causes: Infection with Plasmodium parasites (P. falciparum is most common and dangerous in Africa)
Bite from an infected female Anopheles mosquito
Mother-to-child transmission during pregnancy or birth (congenital malaria)
Rarely, through blood transfusion or shared needles
prevention: Consistent use of Long-Lasting Insecticidal Nets (LLINs)
Indoor Residual Spraying (IRS) of insecticides
Wearing long-sleeved clothing and using repellents, especially at dusk and dawn
Taking antimalarial prophylaxis for pregnant women (Intermittent Preventive Treatment - IPTp)
Removing or treating standing water sources around the home
treatment: Artemisinin-based Combination Therapy (ACT) is first-line treatment (e.g., Artemether-Lumefantrine)
Prompt diagnosis via Rapid Diagnostic Test (RDT) or blood smear microscopy
Severe malaria requires injectable artesunate and hospital care for complications
Paracetamol for fever; avoid aspirin
advice: Malaria is a medical emergency, especially in children and pregnant women. Seek treatment within 24 hours of symptom onset.
Complete the full course of ACT even if symptoms improve to prevent recurrence and drug resistance.
Ensure your net has no holes and is properly tucked in every night.
malawi_context: Malaria is hyperendemic and a leading cause of morbidity and mortality, particularly among children under 5 and pregnant women.
The Ministry of Health and partners conduct mass LLIN distribution campaigns every few years.
Community Health Workers are trained to test and treat uncomplicated malaria at the village level, improving access.

signs: Acute HIV (2-4 weeks post-infection): Fever, sore throat, rash, swollen lymph nodes
Clinical Latency Stage: Often asymptomatic for years
Symptomatic HIV: Persistent fever, night sweats, chronic diarrhea, rapid weight loss (wasting)
Opportunistic Infections: Oral thrush, shingles, persistent herpes, tuberculosis, severe pneumonia
AIDS-Defining Illnesses: Kaposi's sarcoma, cryptococcal meningitis, certain lymphomas
causes: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) infection
Unprotected sexual intercourse with an infected person
Sharing contaminated needles and syringes
Mother-to-child transmission during pregnancy, childbirth, or breastfeeding
Transfusion with infected blood products (now rare due to screening)
prevention: Consistent and correct use of condoms during sex
Voluntary Medical Male Circumcision (VMMC) reduces female-to-male transmission risk
Pre-Exposure Prophylaxis (PrEP) for high-risk individuals
Using sterile needles and equipment
Prevention of Mother-To-Child Transmission (PMTCT) programs involving antiretroviral therapy (ART)
treatment: Antiretroviral Therapy (ART) is lifelong. It involves a combination of drugs from different classes.
ART suppresses the virus, allowing the immune system to recover and preventing progression to AIDS.
Treatment of opportunistic infections as they occur.
Nutritional support to manage wasting.
advice: Know your status through regular testing. Silence and stigma fuel the epidemic.
If positive, start ART immediately and adhere to it perfectly to live a long, healthy life and prevent transmission.
If negative, use prevention methods consistently to stay negative.
malawi_context: Malawi has a high HIV prevalence, though significant progress has been made.
The 'Test and Treat' policy means anyone testing positive starts ART immediately, regardless of CD4 count.
PMTCT programs are widely available, dramatically reducing transmission to newborns.
Stigma remains a significant barrier to testing and adherence.

signs: Persistent cough for more than 2 weeks (sometimes with blood)
Chest pain
Unintentional weight loss and loss of appetite
Fever and night sweats
Fatigue and weakness
In Extrapulmonary TB: Swollen lymph nodes, back pain (spinal TB), confusion (TB meningitis)
causes: Infection with the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis
Inhaling droplets from the cough or sneeze of an infected person
People with weakened immune systems (e.g., HIV) are at much higher risk of active TB
prevention: Bacille Calmette-Guérin (BCG) vaccination in childhood (protects against severe forms in children)
Early diagnosis and complete treatment of active TB cases to stop transmission
Preventive Therapy (TPT) for people living with HIV and contacts of TB patients
Good ventilation in living and working spaces
treatment: A multi-drug regimen for 6+ months. First-line drugs include Isoniazid, Rifampicin, Pyrazinamide, and Ethambutol.
Directly Observed Therapy (DOT) is recommended to ensure adherence and prevent drug resistance.
Drug-Resistant TB (MDR/RR-TB) requires longer, more complex, and more expensive regimens.
advice: Complete the full course of treatment. Stopping early leads to relapse and drug-resistant TB, which is harder and costlier to treat.
Cover your mouth and nose when coughing or sneezing.
If you have a chronic cough, get tested for TB, especially if you are HIV-positive.
malawi_context: TB is a major public health problem, heavily linked with the HIV epidemic.
Integrated HIV/TB services are common, with testing for both offered together.
GeneXpert machines are used for rapid molecular diagnosis, which also tests for Rifampicin resistance.
Community DOT supporters help patients adhere to treatment.

signs: Profuse, watery diarrhea often described as 'rice-water stools'
Rapid dehydration
Vomiting
Muscle cramps due to electrolyte loss
In severe cases: Sunken eyes, loss of skin elasticity, low blood pressure, shock
causes: Infection with the bacterium Vibrio cholerae
Drinking water or eating food contaminated with the feces of an infected person
Often linked to inadequate sanitation and poor hygiene
prevention: Drink safe, treated water (boiled, chlorinated, or bottled)
Practice frequent handwashing with soap and clean water, especially after using the toilet and before eating
Use proper sanitation facilities; avoid open defecation
Eat thoroughly cooked food and peel fruits and vegetables yourself
Oral Cholera Vaccines (OCV) in outbreak situations
treatment: Rapid Rehydration is the cornerstone of treatment. Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) for mild/moderate cases.
Intravenous (IV) fluids (e.g., Ringer's Lactate) for severe dehydration.
Antibiotics can reduce the duration and volume of diarrhea in severe cases.
Zinc supplements for children to reduce severity.
advice: Cholera can kill within hours if untreated. Seek medical help immediately at the first sign of severe, watery diarrhea.
Prepare and use ORS at home at the first sign of diarrhea. Keep packets stocked.
During an outbreak, be extra vigilant about water and food safety.
malawi_context: Cholera outbreaks occur, especially during the rainy season and in overcrowded areas with poor sanitation.
The Ministry of Health leads outbreak response, setting up Cholera Treatment Units (CTUs) in affected areas.
Public health messages on hygiene and water treatment are intensified during outbreaks.

signs: Often called the 'silent killer' because it may have no obvious symptoms for years
Severe hypertension may cause: Headaches, shortness of breath, nosebleeds, flushing, dizziness
Symptoms are often related to long-term damage to organs (heart, kidneys, brain, eyes)
causes: Primary (Essential) Hypertension: No identifiable cause, develops gradually with age (lifestyle factors: high salt diet, obesity, lack of exercise, alcohol, stress)
Secondary Hypertension: Caused by an underlying condition (kidney disease, thyroid problems, sleep apnea)
prevention: Reduce salt (sodium) intake
Eat a balanced diet rich in fruits and vegetables
Maintain a healthy weight
Exercise regularly
Limit alcohol consumption
Avoid tobacco use
Manage stress
Get regular blood pressure check-ups
treatment: Lifelong lifestyle modifications are essential.
Antihypertensive medications (e.g., Thiazide diuretics, ACE inhibitors, Calcium channel blockers) as prescribed.
Regular monitoring to ensure blood pressure is controlled.
advice: Get your blood pressure checked at least once a year, even if you feel fine.
Hypertension is a major risk factor for heart attack, stroke, and kidney failure. Take it seriously.
If prescribed medication, take it consistently. Do not stop because you 'feel fine'.
malawi_context: Hypertension is a growing non-communicable disease (NCD) burden in Malawi, linked to urbanization and changing lifestyles.
Screening is increasingly integrated into primary healthcare, including HIV clinics.
Access to affordable, long-term medication can be a challenge for some patients.

signs: Cough (may produce phlegm/mucus)
Fever, sweating, and chills
Shortness of breath or rapid, shallow breathing
Chest pain that worsens when breathing or coughing
Fatigue and loss of appetite
In infants: Inability to feed, grunting, convulsions, unconsciousness
causes: Infection inflaming the air sacs in one or both lungs, which may fill with fluid or pus.
Bacteria (e.g., Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae)
Viruses (e.g., RSV, influenza, SARS-CoV-2)
Fungi (less common, in immunocompromised individuals)
prevention: Vaccination: Pneumococcal Conjugate Vaccine (PCV) and Hib vaccine for children; Pneumococcal Polysaccharide Vaccine (PPV) for adults; Influenza vaccine.
Exclusive breastfeeding for the first 6 months of life.
Good nutrition to strengthen the immune system.
Reducing indoor air pollution (e.g., from cooking with solid fuels).
Handwashing and cough etiquette.
treatment: Bacterial pneumonia: Treated with antibiotics. The choice depends on severity and age.
Viral pneumonia: Supportive care (rest, fluids, fever control); antibiotics are not effective.
Oxygen therapy for low blood oxygen levels.
Hospitalization for severe cases, especially in young children, the elderly, and those with comorbidities.
advice: A cough with high fever and difficulty breathing is a danger sign, especially in children. Seek care immediately.
Complete the full course of antibiotics if prescribed.
Ensure children receive all recommended vaccinations on schedule.
malawi_context: Pneumonia is a leading cause of death in children under 5 in Malawi.
PCV is part of the routine childhood immunization schedule.
Community-Based Management of Childhood Illness (CBIMCI) trains health workers to diagnose and treat pneumonia at the community level.

signs: Prolonged high fever that gradually increases
Headache and general body weakness
Stomach pain and discomfort
Constipation or diarrhea (more common in children)
Rose-colored spots on the chest and abdomen
Loss of appetite and weight loss
causes: Infection with the bacterium Salmonella Typhi
Consuming food or water contaminated with the feces of an infected person or a chronic carrier
prevention: Drink safe water and use it for brushing teeth and making ice.
Practice thorough handwashing with soap.
Eat food that is thoroughly cooked and still hot.
Avoid raw vegetables and fruits that cannot be peeled.
Get vaccinated against typhoid fever, especially when traveling to high-risk areas.
treatment: Antibiotics are the only effective treatment (e.g., Ciprofloxacin, Azithromycin, Ceftriaxone). Drug resistance is a problem.
Rehydration and management of symptoms like fever.
Severe cases may require hospitalization.
advice: Typhoid fever requires antibiotic treatment; it will not get better on its own.
Even after recovery, some people become chronic carriers and can spread the bacteria. Follow up with your doctor.
Be extremely careful with street food and untreated water.
malawi_context: Typhoid is endemic, with outbreaks common in urban and peri-urban areas with water and sanitation challenges.
Diagnosis can be challenging, often based on clinical signs and the Widal test, which has limitations.

signs: Fever or chills
Dry cough
Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing
Fatigue
Muscle or body aches
Loss of taste or smell
Sore throat
Headache
In severe cases: Pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome
causes: Infection with the SARS-CoV-2 virus
Primarily spread through respiratory droplets when an infected person coughs, sneezes, or talks
Touching contaminated surfaces and then touching the face (less common)
prevention: Vaccination and booster doses as recommended.
Wearing well-fitting masks in crowded indoor settings.
Physical distancing (at least 1 meter).
Good ventilation in indoor spaces.
Frequent hand hygiene with soap or alcohol-based sanitizer.
Covering coughs and sneezes.
Staying home and testing if you have symptoms.
treatment: Most cases are mild and managed with rest, hydration, and fever reducers (paracetamol).
For high-risk individuals, antiviral medications (e.g., Paxlovid) may be used early to prevent severe illness.
Severe cases require hospital care, including oxygen support and steroids (e.g., Dexamethasone).
advice: Stay up-to-date with recommended COVID-19 vaccinations.
If you are at high risk for severe disease and test positive, contact your doctor immediately about treatment options.
Isolate yourself if you have symptoms to protect others.
malawi_context: Malawi has experienced multiple waves of COVID-19.
Vaccines are available, though vaccine hesitancy has been a challenge.
The pandemic put a strain on the health system and highlighted the need for stronger public health infrastructure.

signs: Wheezing (a whistling sound when breathing out)
Shortness of breath
Chest tightness or pain
Coughing, especially at night or early morning
Symptoms are often triggered and can vary over time
causes: Exact cause unknown, but involves a combination of genetic and environmental factors.
Airway inflammation and hyperreactivity to triggers.
Common Triggers: Allergens (dust mites, pollen, mold), tobacco smoke, air pollution, cold air, exercise, respiratory infections.
prevention: Identify and avoid personal asthma triggers.
Use controller medications as prescribed to reduce underlying inflammation.
Get a flu shot annually.
Create an Asthma Action Plan with your doctor.
treatment: Quick-Relief Inhalers (e.g., Salbutamol) for rapid relief during an attack.
Long-Term Control Medications (e.g., Inhaled Corticosteroids) taken daily to prevent symptoms and attacks.
In severe attacks, oral steroids and emergency medical care may be needed.
advice: Asthma is a chronic condition that can be controlled, allowing for a normal, active life.
Learn to use your inhaler correctly for the medicine to reach your lungs.
Don't ignore worsening symptoms. Follow your Asthma Action Plan.
malawi_context: Asthma is under-diagnosed and often mistaken for recurrent bronchitis or TB.
Access to inhalers and spacers can be limited, and cost is a barrier for many.
Burning of biomass fuels for cooking is a significant trigger in many households.

signs: Loose, watery stools three or more times a day
Abdominal cramps and pain
Urgent need to have a bowel movement
Nausea and vomiting
Fever
Signs of dehydration: Thirst, dry mouth, little urine, lethargy, sunken eyes
causes: Viruses (e.g., Rotavirus, Norovirus) - most common cause
Bacteria (e.g., E. coli, Salmonella, Shigella) from contaminated food/water
Parasites (e.g., Giardia)
Malnutrition, making children more susceptible
Poor sanitation and hygiene
prevention: Exclusive breastfeeding for the first 6 months.
Rotavirus vaccination.
Frequent handwashing with soap.
Use of improved sanitation facilities and safe drinking water.
Good food hygiene practices.
treatment: Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) is the key treatment to prevent and treat dehydration.
Zinc supplements for 10-14 days reduce severity and duration and prevent future episodes.
Continued feeding and breastfeeding to maintain nutrition.
Antibiotics are only for specific bacterial causes, not for most cases.
advice: The main danger of diarrhea is dehydration. Start giving ORS at the first sign of diarrhea.
Do not give anti-diarrheal medicines to children; they can be harmful.
Seek medical help if there is blood in stool, persistent vomiting, or signs of severe dehydration.
malawi_context: Diarrhea is a leading cause of childhood mortality, linked to poor WASH (Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene) conditions.
Rotavirus vaccine is part of the national immunization program.
Community Health Workers promote the use of ORS and zinc.

signs: Type 1: Frequent urination, excessive thirst, extreme hunger, unintended weight loss, fatigue.
Type 2: Often develops slowly; can include the same symptoms as Type 1, plus blurred vision, slow-healing sores, frequent infections, and areas of darkened skin (acanthosis nigricans).
causes: Type 1 Diabetes: Autoimmune destruction of insulin-producing cells in the pancreas. Cause not fully known.
Type 2 Diabetes: Develops due to insulin resistance (body doesn't use insulin well) and eventually reduced insulin production. Strongly linked to obesity, physical inactivity, and genetics.
Gestational Diabetes: Occurs during pregnancy.
prevention: Type 1: Cannot be prevented currently.
Type 2: Maintain a healthy weight, eat a balanced diet, engage in regular physical activity, avoid tobacco use.
treatment: Type 1: Lifelong insulin therapy (injections or pump), blood sugar monitoring, carbohydrate counting.
Type 2: Lifestyle changes are foundational. Oral medications (e.g., Metformin) and/or injectable medications (including insulin) are often needed over time.
Regular foot and eye exams to screen for complications.
advice: Diabetes is a chronic condition that requires daily self-management.
Uncontrolled diabetes can lead to heart disease, stroke, kidney failure, blindness, and limb amputation.
Work with your healthcare team to create a personalized management plan.
malawi_context: The prevalence of Type 2 Diabetes is rising rapidly due to lifestyle changes.
Access to insulin, test strips, and specialized care is a significant challenge, especially in rural areas.
There is a lot of misinformation and stigma associated with the disease.

signs: Acute Infection: Fatigue, fever, loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, dark urine, clay-colored stools, joint pain, jaundice.
Chronic Infection: May have no symptoms for decades until complications like cirrhosis or liver cancer develop.
causes: Infection with the Hepatitis B virus (HBV)
Contact with infectious blood, semen, and other body fluids.
Mother-to-child transmission during birth.
Unprotected sex with an infected partner.
Sharing needles, syringes, or other drug-injection equipment.
Unsafe blood transfisions or medical procedures.
prevention: Hepatitis B vaccination is the most effective prevention (part of the childhood immunization schedule).
Practice safe sex by using condoms.
Do not share needles, razors, or toothbrushes.
Ensure safe blood transfusion practices and sterile medical equipment.
treatment: Acute Hepatitis B: Usually managed with supportive care (rest, nutrition, fluids).
Chronic Hepatitis B: Requires lifelong monitoring. Antiviral medications (e.g., Tenofovir, Entecavir) can suppress the virus and reduce liver damage but rarely cure it.
advice: Get vaccinated if you haven't been. It's a safe and effective vaccine.
If you are chronically infected, avoid alcohol as it can accelerate liver damage.
Get regular check-ups to monitor your liver health.
malawi_context: Hepatitis B is highly endemic in sub-Saharan Africa, including Malawi.
The vaccine was introduced into the routine infant immunization schedule, which will reduce the burden in future generations.
Screening and treatment for chronic HBV are not yet widely accessible.

signs: Joint pain, tenderness, and stiffness
Inflammation, swelling, and redness around the joint
Reduced range of motion
Warmth in the affected area
Symptoms are often worse in the morning
causes: Osteoarthritis: 'Wear and tear' damage to joint cartilage over time.
Rheumatoid Arthritis: An autoimmune disorder where the immune system attacks the joints.
Gout: Buildup of uric acid crystals in the joint.
Other causes: Infections, underlying diseases.
prevention: Maintain a healthy weight to reduce stress on joints.
Exercise regularly to strengthen muscles around joints.
Use proper techniques when lifting or moving heavy objects.
Protect joints from injury.
treatment: Medications: Pain relievers (e.g., Paracetamol), NSAIDs (e.g., Ibuprofen), disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) for rheumatoid arthritis.
Physical therapy to improve strength and range of motion.
Lifestyle changes: Weight loss, exercise.
In severe cases, joint replacement surgery may be an option.
advice: Arthritis is not just 'old age'; it can affect people of all ages.
Stay active. Inactivity can make joints stiffer and more painful.
Work with a doctor to find a treatment plan that manages pain and maintains joint function.
malawi_context: Arthritis is often misunderstood and poorly managed due to limited access to specialists like rheumatologists.
Pain management often relies on basic painkillers, which may not be sufficient for inflammatory types like rheumatoid arthritis.
Traditional healers are often consulted for joint pain.

signs: Sudden high fever
Severe headache
Stiff neck
Nausea or vomiting
Confusion or difficulty concentrating
Sensitivity to light (photophobia)
Sleepiness or difficulty waking
In infants: Bulging fontanelle (soft spot on head), inactivity, poor feeding, a high-pitched cry
causes: Viral Meningitis: Most common, usually less severe. Caused by various viruses.
Bacterial Meningitis: Less common but very serious and life-threatening. Caused by bacteria like Neisseria meningitidis, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae.
Fungal Meningitis: Rare, in immunocompromised people.
prevention: Vaccination: Meningococcal, Pneumococcal, and Hib vaccines protect against the main bacterial causes.
Good hygiene (handwashing, not sharing utensils/ drinks).
For close contacts of a bacterial meningitis case, prophylactic antibiotics may be given.
treatment: Bacterial Meningitis: A medical emergency requiring immediate hospitalization and intravenous antibiotics.
Viral Meningitis: Usually resolves on its own with supportive care (rest, fluids, pain medication).
Fungal Meningitis: Treated with long courses of antifungal drugs.
advice: Bacterial meningitis can kill within hours. If you suspect meningitis (especially with stiff neck and fever), seek emergency care immediately.
Early antibiotic treatment is critical for survival and to reduce the risk of permanent disabilities like brain damage or hearing loss.
malawi_context: Malawi lies in the 'Meningitis Belt' of Africa and is at risk for epidemics, particularly of Meningococcal Meningitis.
Vaccination campaigns are conducted in response to outbreaks.
Diagnosis can be challenging as it requires a lumbar puncture (spinal tap), which is not available at all health centers.

signs: A strong, persistent urge to urinate
A burning sensation when urinating
Passing frequent, small amounts of urine
Cloudy, dark, bloody, or strong-smelling urine
Pelvic pain in women
Rectal pain in men
causes: Bacteria (most commonly E. coli from the digestive tract) entering the urethra and multiplying in the urinary tract.
Risk factors: Female anatomy (shorter urethra), sexual activity, certain types of birth control, menopause, urinary tract abnormalities, blockages (e.g., kidney stones).
prevention: Drink plenty of water to flush out bacteria.
Wipe from front to back after using the toilet.
Urinate soon after sexual intercourse.
Avoid potentially irritating feminine products (douches, powders).
treatment: Antibiotics are the standard treatment. The type and duration depend on the bacteria and the patient's health.
Pain relievers can help relieve the burning sensation.
Uncomplicated UTIs are usually cured with a short course of antibiotics.
advice: Drink cranberry juice or take supplements; it may help prevent recurrent UTIs in some people, though evidence is mixed.
Do not delay urination when you feel the urge.
Finish the entire course of antibiotics, even if you start to feel better.
malawi_context: UTIs are common but often self-treated or misdiagnosed.
Access to laboratory testing for urine culture is limited, so diagnosis is often based on symptoms alone.
Antibiotic resistance is a growing concern due to inappropriate use.

signs: High fever (can spike to 104°F/40°C)
Cough, runny nose, red and watery eyes (conjunctivitis)
Koplik's spots (tiny white spots with bluish-white centers on a red background) inside the mouth.
A red, blotchy rash that starts on the face and hairline, then spreads downward to the rest of the body.
causes: Infection with the highly contagious measles virus (rubeola).
Spread through the air by coughing and sneezing, or by direct contact with infected nasal or throat secretions.
prevention: Vaccination with the Measles, Mumps, and Rubella (MMR) vaccine is highly effective. Two doses are recommended.
Isolation of infected individuals to prevent spread.
treatment: No specific antiviral treatment.
Supportive care to relieve symptoms: rest, fluids, fever reducers (avoid aspirin in children).
Vitamin A supplementation is recommended for children with measles in developing countries to reduce the risk of complications and death.
Treatment of complications like pneumonia or ear infections.
advice: Measles is one of the most contagious diseases. Vaccination is crucial for herd immunity.
Complications can be severe and include pneumonia, encephalitis (brain swelling), blindness, and death, especially in malnourished children.
If you suspect measles, contact a health facility but inform them beforehand so they can take precautions to prevent spread.
malawi_context: Malawi conducts periodic mass measles vaccination campaigns to reach all children, alongside routine immunization.
Outbreaks can occur when vaccination coverage drops.
Malnutrition increases the risk of severe and fatal measles.

signs: Varies greatly by type and location:
Skin (Ringworm, Athlete's Foot): Itchy, red, scaly, circular rash.
Nails (Onychomycosis): Thickened, discolored, brittle nails.
Vaginal Yeast Infection: Itching, burning, thick white discharge.
Thrush (Oral Candidiasis): White patches on tongue/in mouth.
Systemic: Fever, cough, weight loss (e.g., in cryptococcal meningitis, common in advanced HIV).
causes: Contact with fungi (dermatophytes, yeasts, molds).
Thrives in warm, moist environments (skin folds, sweaty feet).
Weakened immune system (e.g., HIV) is a major risk factor for severe and systemic fungal infections.
Antibiotic use can disrupt normal flora and allow yeast overgrowth.
prevention: Keep skin clean and dry.
Wear breathable clothing and footwear.
Don't walk barefoot in public showers/pools.
Practice good hygiene and don't share personal items like towels or combs.
For people with HIV, taking co-trimoxazole prophylaxis helps prevent some fungal infections.
treatment: Topical antifungals: Creams, powders, or sprays for skin infections.
Oral antifungals: Tablets for severe or persistent skin infections, nail infections, and systemic infections (e.g., Fluconazole, Itraconazole).
advice: Do not use steroid creams (which reduce inflammation) on a fungal rash unless prescribed, as they can make the infection worse.
Complete the full course of antifungal treatment, even if the rash seems to be gone.
See a doctor for infections that don't improve with over-the-counter treatments.
malawi_context: Superficial fungal infections are very common due to the warm climate.
Cryptococcal meningitis is a major opportunistic infection and cause of death in people with advanced HIV/AIDS.
Access to diagnostics for systemic fungal infections and to some oral antifungal drugs can be limited.

signs: Common Cold: Runny/stuffy nose, sore throat, sneezing, cough, mild fever, slight body aches.
Influenza (Flu): Sudden onset of HIGH fever, dry cough, sore throat, severe muscle/body aches, headache, extreme tiredness. Can lead to pneumonia.
causes: Common Cold: Caused by many different viruses (e.g., Rhinoviruses).
Influenza: Caused by Influenza viruses (Types A, B, and C).
prevention: Annual flu vaccination is the best way to prevent influenza.
Frequent handwashing with soap and water.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth.
Avoid close contact with sick people.
Cover your mouth and nose when coughing or sneezing.
treatment: Rest and drink plenty of fluids.
Use over-the-counter medicines to relieve symptoms (e.g., paracetamol for fever/pain).
Antiviral drugs for influenza (e.g., Oseltamivir) can reduce severity and duration if started early, but are not effective for the common cold.
advice: Antibiotics do not work against cold and flu viruses.
The flu can be very serious for young children, the elderly, pregnant women, and people with chronic illnesses. They should be vaccinated.
Stay home when you are sick to avoid spreading the illness.
malawi_context: Influenza circulates year-round in tropical climates like Malawi's, with peaks during the rainy season.
The common cold is often referred to locally as 'flu', leading to confusion with actual influenza.
Flu vaccines are available but not widely used in the general population, typically targeted at high-risk groups.

signs: Undernutrition (Wasting, Stunting, Underweight): Low weight-for-height (wasting), low height-for-age (stunting), low weight-for-age (underweight). Fatigue, dizziness, swollen belly, poor growth in children.
Overnutrition (Overweight/Obesity): Excess body fat, high body mass index (BMI).
Micronutrient Deficiencies: Various signs (e.g., night blindness-Vitamin A, anemia-Iron, goiter-Iodine).
causes: Undernutrition: Not eating enough food, lack of nutritious food, recurrent infections (diarrhea, worms) that prevent nutrient absorption, poor childcare practices.
Overnutrition: Consuming more calories than the body uses, often from diets high in fat and sugar and low physical activity.
prevention: Exclusive breastfeeding for first 6 months, continued breastfeeding with appropriate complementary foods up to 2 years.
Diverse diet including fruits, vegetables, and protein sources.
Treatment and prevention of infectious diseases.
Food fortification (e.g., iodized salt).
Public health education on nutrition.
treatment: Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM): Therapeutic ready-to-use therapeutic food (RUTF), treatment of medical complications.
Moderate Acute Malnutrition (MAM): Supplementary feeding, nutritional counseling.
Overnutrition: Dietary changes, increased physical activity, behavior modification.
advice: Malnutrition is not just about hunger; it's about the quality of the diet.
The first 1000 days of life (from pregnancy to a child's second birthday) are the most critical for preventing lifelong effects of malnutrition.
A malnourished child is much more vulnerable to infections, and infections can make malnutrition worse—a vicious cycle.
malawi_context: Malnutrition, particularly stunting in children under 5, remains a severe public health problem.
It is a complex issue driven by poverty, food insecurity, and suboptimal infant and young child feeding practices.
Programs by the government and NGOs focus on promoting agriculture, nutrition education, and managing acute malnutrition at the community level.
